COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Methodologies and exercises on contextual design and environmentally sound technologies (EST's) applications for the sustainability of urban infrastructures, operative landscapes, and building integration in the urban system.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: a. Introduction to behavior and analysis of building structures. Structural loading, materials, and element types will be explored to understand the basic building blocks of buildings. b. Investigation and design of building structural systems for gravity, wind and seismic loading. Comprehensive des ign exploration of framing type, materials, detailing, layout, form and integration. Recommended preparation: One-semester college-level course in physics or calculus.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Design methodology, typology programming, site analysis, budget formulation and pro-forma procedures. Office management, emphasizing professional service and professional ethics as well as project management focusing on the architect's responsibilities during construction.
DEPTOWNERNAME: School of Architecture

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Design methodology, typology programming, site analysis, budget formulation and pro-forma procedures. COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Applications and precedents for the architect interested indesigning multi-family housing.Review of the sources of modern housing types, the impact of building codes and technology on the form and construction of housing, and study of housing densities, comparative analysis of multi-family residential patterns.Major emphasis on critical knowledge of historic housing typologies as they are applied to site conditions and groupings, building form, section, organization, and the design of individual dwellings. Recommended preparation: two years of undergraduate architectural studies.
DEPTOWNERNAME: School of Architecture

COURSE_TITLE: Urban Housing: Programs, Precedents, and Recent Case Studies
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Historical overview of the major domestic and international housing developments and innovations since the early 20th century case study format examining a wide range of issues that determine the form of urban housing in various cultures. Major emphasis on the detail analysis of social, technical, a nd design factors affecting recent housing developments. Recommended preparation: two years of undergraduate architectural studies.

DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Rhetorical and critical approaches to sports and public discourse; application to sports organizations, the news and popular media; representations of gender and race in sports.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Popular culture as an indicator of cultural values, a producer and reflection of cultural meaning, and a means of communication; theory and case studies.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: How communication processes both create organizations and are constrained by them. Theory and research into topics such as culture, technology, power, leadership and decision-making in a variety of organizational contexts.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Application of critical, sociological and rhetorical theories to sports events and sport media; examination of the role of sports in enacting social change.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Social and political movements as rhetorical phenomena; ideology, organization, and influence of such movements as civil rights, "New Left," feminism, "New Right," environmentalism.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

DEPTOWNERNAME: Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Problems in political communication: creating an informed electorate, use of mass media, factors in voter persuasion. Guest experts in political analysis, opinion polling, communication evaluation.

DEPTOWNERNAME: Roski School of Art and Design

COURSE_TITLE: Methods of Curating: Introduction to Curatorial Practicum
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: First in a sequence of three courses on history/theory of curatorial methods, with practical experience necessary to mounting exhibitions and devising interfaces with the public. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 555a)
DEPTOWNERNAME: Roski School of Art and Design

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Third in a sequence of three courses on history/theory of curatorial methods, with practical experience necessary to mounting exhibitions and devising interfaces with the public. Prerequisite: CRIT 556. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 555c)
DEPTOWNERNAME: Roski School of Art and Design

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Exploration of interrelated themes that examine how the time-based art of theatre intersects with other art forms and surpasses its preexisting boundaries.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Roski School of Art and Design

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 590)
DEPTOWNERNAME: Roski School of Art and Design

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Supervised internship in an art institution or an art agency, or with an independent curator or artist, on projects and research specific to public space. Recommended preparation: Completion of first year of courses. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 591)
DEPTOWNERNAME: Roski School of Art and Design

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: A human capital interpretation of labor demand and supply; wagedetermination, differentials, and discrimination; job turnover and occupational mobility; unions and collective bargaining.

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

Assists students understanding how to use time series data to test hypotheses and serve as an introduction to the ideas and techniques of forecasting.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Analyze how psychology and behavioral economics together contribute to our understanding of decision-making: inter-temporal choice, self-control problems, cooperative and risky behavior, social preferences.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Classical economic theory; its precursors, main contributors, extensions and critics; focus upon the writings and ideas of Smith, Say, Malthus, Ricardo, Mill and Marx.

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. Students must have a specific job/internship offer. Job must be related to students major. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. Students must have been in F-1 student status for at least one academic year in a degree-seeking program before they can apply for CPT, with a cumulative 3.0 GPA. Course does not apply to degree credit. Open only to graduate students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: General equilibrium theory; existence, uniqueness, and stability; welfare economics; social choice; dynamic models and uncertainty; special topics. Prerequisite: ECON-601.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Strategies and equilibrium concepts; dynamic and repeated games; incomplete information and learning in games. Prerequisite: ECON-601.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Macroeconomic theory based on the concepts of optimal growth and intertemporal equilibrium; overlapping generations models; recent developments in macroeconomic theory. Prerequisites: ECON-601 and ECON-602.

COURSE_TITLE: Gerontology: The Science of Adult Development
INSTRUCTOR_NAME: Walsh, John, P Walsh, Julia, R. Mastro, Tara
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduction to adult development through the lifespan;biological, psychological, and social processes; gerontology as a career for the future.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_TITLE: Medical Issues of Older Persons: An Introduction to Geriatrics
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Clinical cases for understanding changes occurring with normal aging, health behaviors that modify age-dependent diseases and history, prevention and treatment of age-related diseases and disorders.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduction to the brain and mind. A unique multimedia approach to stress how knowledge about the mind is gained from scientific and clinical investigations.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: How psychologists study thinking, memory, emotions, personality, and behavior, and how people change in these throughout adulthood to old age.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: An introduction to the core curriculum in the study of Gerontology. Research perspectives on adult development and aging; methodological issues; personality and relationship issues; general mental and emotional components of aging; research methods.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_TITLE: Policy, Values, and Power in an Aging Society
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: How Americans' political values affect public policy. Studies of landmark legislation to explore the social contract between generations and role of governments in social welfare.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Exploring diversity in the older population and variability in the human aging process.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Explores nutritional needs and the physiological, psychological, and sociological relationships to nutrition. Laboratory experiments in assessment and evaluation.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_TITLE: Exercise and Aging: Principles and Programs
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Physiological, psychological, and sociological aspects of exercise. Laboratory involvement in assessment and evaluation of fitness.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_TITLE: Exercise and Aging: Principles and Programs
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Physiological, psychological, and sociological aspects of exercise. Laboratory involvement in assessment and evaluation of fitness.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Age-related changes in nervous system structure and function; relationship of brain changes to changes in cognitive function and perception; Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Methods of studying, evaluating, and treating cognitive, psychiatric, and behavioral problems associated with medical conditions of old age.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Physiological, psychological, and social health problems of adults as they are impacted by health choices throughout life.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_TITLE: Women and Aging: Psychological, Social, andPolitical Implications
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Problems and resources of the middle-aged and older woman in a changing society; including discrimination, stereotypes, employment, social interaction, etc.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_TITLE: Social and Psychological Aspects of Death and Dying
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduction and critical survey of the current issues, concepts, and research of the social and psychological aspects of death and dying.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Consideration of the biological and social-cultural factors that govern the evolution of life spans and the life of humans and selected animal models. Recommended preparation: statistics
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Overview of the concepts, characteristics, skills, and clinicalissues of case management in a variety of settings serving older persons.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_TITLE: Finding the Key to a Long, Happy Life in Nicoya, Costa Rica
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Immersion into lifestyles shown to improve quality of life and extend lifespan by studying populations in "Blue Zone" communities throughout the world.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Supervised experience in one or more community agencies.Graded CR/NC.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Leonard Davis School of Gerontology

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: An in-depth integration of major research and professional themesin the study of human development and aging.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduction to and discussion on clinically relevant topics such as social determinants of health, medical ethics and legal and regulatory aspects, in preparation for experience in the clinical setting.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: An introduction to professionalism and skills required in the practice of medicine and careers in health care.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Examination of fundamental ethical concepts and principles in clinical health care and biomedical research. Use of film, case studies and discussion. Recommended Preparation: MDA-110 or MEDS-220.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

DEPTOWNERNAME: Ostrow School of Dentistry

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Applications of sensory integration theory and intervention principles in diverse therapeutic contexts, including school-based settings, early intervention, autism spectrum disorders, and feeding and eating.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Ostrow School of Dentistry

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Study of major trends in Latin American fiction from the 1930s to the present with a focus on narrative experimentation.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_TITLE: The Culture of Food in Hispanic Los Angeles

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Explore Oaxaca's mountains, beaches, villages and capital city; first hand experience in culture, traditional food, street artists and agricultural systems.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: A study of the cultures of Peru in the context of their history and languages, with a focus on Quechua, music, dances and cuisine.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS- Humanities
